I just would like to point out that, in my opinion, part of the disagreemen=
t between you and Jeff and Ken comes from the fact that Ken somehow made th=
e statement "it is better to implement the bias in the encoding than in the=
 fitness function" but in actual fact argues for a specific type of impleme=
ntation in the encoding.

Thus, I thing the discussion should not center ar=
ound the general question whether a bias should be incorporated in the fitn=
ess or in the encoding because in both areas there are better and worse way=
s to do it. The question is more, why a specific implementation (that Ken h=
as obviously in mind, my impression was he thought about approaches similar=
 to LEO) is better than another.

My question to Ken would be here: what is=
 the additional ingredient that makes a bias in the encoding better / more =
plausible than *any* implementation of the bias in the fitness function?
